headline: Is the Pennsylvania GOP Senate primary over because Trump endorsed Dr. Oz?
author: Paul Muschick
sentences:
“When I’m Governor, we’re going to get back to a voting system that everyone has confidence in, and that begins with repealing the unconstitutional mail-in balloting law, Act 77, that Doug Mastriano voted for.”
So Mastriano’s campaign issued a statement Tuesday evening, just to make sure we know he’s still out there.

“I will continue to fight for election integrity and as governor I’ll have the power to ensure that our elections are administered correctly and lawfully.”
There are plenty of moderate Republicans — those with a brain who are willing to think for themselves — who disdain the former commander-in-chief.

“Two developments today have led me to decide to remain in the race for governor: President Trump’s statement on the race and my conversation directly with the president,” Corman, of Centre County, said in a statement.

He knew what was happening and let it go.”
“I’ve prosecuted and put people behind bars who committed voter fraud, and put rioters and looters in jail,” he said in a statement.
“He was the U.S. Attorney who did absolutely nothing on the massive Election Fraud that took place in Philadelphia and throughout the commonwealth.
I wonder if all the Republican candidates in Pennsylvania’s U.S. Senate and gubernatorial races have these commercials produced and ready to go.
Pennsylvanians know the truth about my record and that Act 77 was unconstitutionally rewritten by the PA Supreme Court after its passage.
So it wasn’t shocking that on Tuesday morning, he filed a petition in Commonwealth Court to have his name removed from the ballot.
He is the former U.S. attorney in Philadelphia who led federal prosecutions there and in the Lehigh Valley area under Trump.
Those changes completely undermined our legislative intent and removed critical safeguards prior to the 2020 election.
They’ve focused on beating their chests — and beating each other up — to win the endorsement of The Donald.
The Trump statement that Corman referred to was a bashing of one of Corman’s opponents, William McSwain.
It brags about his endorsement just a few days earlier by former President Donald Trump.
Corman, the president pro tempore of the state Senate, is well behind in the polls.
“Both President Trump and I are fighting the same battles on behalf of the people.
His endorsements could be a road map for who not to vote for in the primary.
I saw the latest campaign commercial for Mehmet Oz on Wednesday morning.
The voters will decide who our next senator and governor will be.
Do not vote for Bill McSwain, a coward, who let our Country down.
And still best buds with the party king.
Have the candidates forgotten that?
And are praying they can air them.
It’s like that’s all that matters.
He’s in a crowded field.
